title: Getting Started
text: installed R RStudio Desktop, can install TrackMateR using devtools
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("quantixed/TrackMateR")

title: Getting Started
text: basic example load one TrackMate XML file analyse . typically tracking session associated single movie (referred single dataset). example data, got warning telling us data scaled pixels. TrackMate data correctly calibrated can skip step need recalibrate : done, can look data.  , reading TrackMate file readTrackMateXML() object can visualise using plot_tm_allTracks(). TrackMateR can generate several different types plot individually using commands like plot_tm_allTracks() can make automatically create report .
code: library(ggplot2) library(TrackMateR) # an example file is provided, otherwise use file.choose() xmlPath <- system.file("extdata", "ExampleTrackMateData.xml", package="TrackMateR") # read the TrackMate XML file into R using tmObj <- readTrackMateXML(XMLpath = xmlPath) #> Units are:  1 pixel and 0.07002736 s  #> Spatial units are in pixels - consider transforming to real units #> Collecting spot data... #> Matching track data... #> Calculating distances... # Pixel size is 0.04 um and original data was 1 pixel, xyscalar = 0.04 tmObj <- correctTrackMateData(dataList = tmObj, xyscalar = 0.04, xyunit = "um") #> Correcting XY scale. plot_tm_allTracks(tmObj) reportDataset(tmObj)

title: Getting Started
text: Perhaps default options suit needs. just lines code, can tweak report analysis want. see dataset read scaled correctly. reading , rescale start generate report. report shows analysis mean squared displacement, jump distance track density, among plots. three things must calculated first using calculateMSD(), calculateJD() calculateTrackDensity. allows control analysis, example setting search radius Track Density. Finally, items can fed makeSummaryReport() shown , report created.  vignette described analysis single dataset. analysis one dataset, see vignette("comparison")
code: # we can get a data frame of the correct TrackMate data  tmDF <- tmObj[[1]] # and a data frame of calibration information calibrationDF <- tmObj[[2]] # we can calculate mean squared displacement msdObj <- calculateMSD(df = tmDF, method = "ensemble", N = 3, short = 8) # and jump distance jdObj <- calculateJD(dataList = tmObj, deltaT = 1) # and look at the density of tracks tdDF <- calculateTrackDensity(dataList = tmObj, radius = 1.5) # if we extract the name of the file fileName <- tools::file_path_sans_ext(basename(xmlPath)) # we can send all these things to makeSummaryReport() to get a nice report of our dataset makeSummaryReport(tmList = tmObj, msdList = msdObj, jumpList = jdObj, tddf = tdDF, titleStr = "Report", subStr = fileName, auto = FALSE)

title: Comparison of multiple datasets
text: Recommended Start new RStudio session new directory using Create Project. find useful follow convention RStudio projects. gist can run console quickly set folder structure new project. Now place data folder called Data/ directory. Required Place TrackMate XML files subfolders according condition. example might : cell1.xml cell2.xml cell1.xml cell2.xml cell3.xml one level folders allowed.

title: Comparison of multiple datasets
text: data place, single command generate series reports, summaries comparison Currently, outputs generated using standard parameters equivalent reportDataset() possibility change parameters.
code: library(TrackMateR) compareDatasets()

title: Comparison of multiple datasets
text: example , code produce following directory called Output/ comparison.pdf combined.pdf report_1.pdf report_2.pdf combined.pdf report_1.pdf report_2.pdf report_3.pdf , individual reports saved new name (regardless original XML filename), datasets combined (per condition) combined.pdf comparison summary conditions saved top level folder (comparison.pdf).

title: Comparison of multiple datasets
text: possible recalibrate TrackMate XML files en masse using CSV file condition subfolder containing XML files. separate CSV file needed condition. conditions need recalibrating simply need CSV file present. CSV file can name must follow format. Using file, XML files folder recalibrated already 0.04 micron pixel size 0.07 s per frame. Adjustments smaller 2.5% ignored. situation datasets differing (correct) timescales spatial units need corrected, use 0 value corresponding time (time rescaling ignored) spatial rescaling go ahead. Similarly, different spatial scaling datasets can rescale time using 0 spatial value. datasets need calibrating differently, need group condition-level subfolders single csv file specify correct parameters. Alternatively, consider going back retracking TrackMate specifying correct parameters.
code: value,unit 0.04,um 0.07,s

title: Authors and Citation
text: Stephen J Royle. Maintainer, author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Royle S (2022). TrackMateR: Working TrackMate outputs R. R package version 0.2.1, https://quantixed.github.io/TrackMateR/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {TrackMateR: Working with TrackMate outputs in R},   author = {Stephen J Royle},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.2.1},   url = {https://quantixed.github.io/TrackMateR/}, }

what: Working with TrackMate outputs in R
title: Working with TrackMate outputs in R
text: Analysis TrackMate XML outputs R. TrackMate single-particle tracking plugin ImageJ/Fiji. standard output tracking session TrackMate XML format. goal R package import data associated final filtered tracks TrackMate analysis visualization R. package development considered stable first release.

title: Working with TrackMate outputs in R
text: installed R RStudio Desktop, can install TrackMateR using devtools
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("quantixed/TrackMateR")

title: Working with TrackMate outputs in R
text: basic example load one TrackMate XML file analyse .  Let’s go bit . TrackMateR can generate several different types plot individually using commands can make automatically create report .
code: library(ggplot2) library(TrackMateR) # an example file is provided, otherwise use file.choose() xmlPath <- system.file("extdata", "ExampleTrackMateData.xml", package="TrackMateR") # read the TrackMate XML file into R using tmObj <- readTrackMateXML(XMLpath = xmlPath) #> Units are:  1 pixel and 0.07002736 s  #> Spatial units are in pixels - consider transforming to real units #> Collecting spot data... #> Matching track data... #> Calculating distances... # have a look at the tracks plot_tm_allTracks(tmObj) # perhaps the data we loaded in was not scaled properly # Pixel size is 0.04 um and original data was 1 pixel, xyscalar = 0.04 tmObj <- correctTrackMateData(dataList = tmObj, xyscalar = 0.04, xyunit = "um") #> Correcting XY scale. # we can get a data frame of the correct TrackMate data  tmDF <- tmObj[[1]] # and a data frame of calibration information calibrationDF <- tmObj[[2]] # we can calculate mean squared displacement msdObj <- calculateMSD(df = tmDF, method = "ensemble", N = 3, short = 8) # and jump distance jdObj <- calculateJD(dataList = tmObj, deltaT = 1) # and look at the density of tracks tdDF <- calculateTrackDensity(dataList = tmObj, radius = 1.5) # if we extract the name of the file fileName <- tools::file_path_sans_ext(basename(xmlPath)) # we can send all these things to makeSummaryReport() to get a nice report of our dataset makeSummaryReport(tmList = tmObj, msdList = msdObj, jumpList = jdObj, tddf = tdDF, titleStr = "Report", subStr = fileName, auto = FALSE)

title: Working with TrackMate outputs in R
text: TrackMateR builds initial work Julien Godet trackR. Méghane Sittewelle provided example TrackMate data helped testing TrackMateR.

what: Calculate alpha (relationship between MSD and normal diffusion) — calculateAlpha
title: Calculate alpha (relationship between MSD and normal diffusion) — calculateAlpha
text: Normal diffusion alpha = 1. Subdiffusion alpha < 1 superdiffusion alpha > 1. Input data matrix msd curves. Output mean log2(alpha), one value trace.

title: Calculate alpha (relationship between MSD and normal diffusion) — calculateAlpha
code: calculateAlpha(alphaMat, tstep)

title: Calculate alpha (relationship between MSD and normal diffusion) — calculateAlpha
text: alphaMat matrix msd curves, col track, row time lag (contain NAs) tstep variable. Time step seconds

title: Calculate alpha (relationship between MSD and normal diffusion) — calculateAlpha
text: numeric vector

title: Calculate Jump Distance (JD) — calculateJD
text: Calculation JD multiple tracks. Calculation equivalent single time lag point ensemble MSD curve, typically represented histogram Input data frame tracks imported using readTrackMateXML() default time step one frame - equivalent plot generated show displacement versus time.

title: Calculate Jump Distance (JD) — calculateJD
code: calculateJD(dataList, deltaT = 1)

title: Calculate Jump Distance (JD) — calculateJD
text: dataList list data frame (must include minimum - trace (track ID), x, y t (real coords)) calibration deltaT integer represent multiple frames analysed

title: Calculate Jump Distance (JD) — calculateJD
text: list data frame jump distances, NAs removed; numeric variable (jumptime)

title: Calculate Jump Distance (JD) — calculateJD
code: xmlPath <- system.file("extdata", "ExampleTrackMateData.xml", package="TrackMateR") tmObj <- readTrackMateXML(XMLpath = xmlPath) #> Units are:  1 pixel and 0.07002736 s  #> Spatial units are in pixels - consider transforming to real units #> Collecting spot data... #> Matching track data... #> Calculating distances... tmObj <- correctTrackMateData(tmObj, xyscalar = 0.04) #> Correcting XY scale.  jdObj <- calculateJD(dataList = tmObj, deltaT = 2)

title: Calculate Mean Squared Displacement (MSD) — calculateMSD
text: Calculation MSD multiple tracks. two methods everaging MSD data multiple tracks: ensemble = time lag average squared displacements tracks time-averaged = find MSD track generate average MSD curves MSD curves identical tracks length, diverge . Standard deviation large ensemble smaller time-averaged data. Input data frame tracks imported using readTrackMateXML()

title: Calculate Mean Squared Displacement (MSD) — calculateMSD
code: calculateMSD(df, method = "timeaveraged", N = 4, short = 0)

title: Calculate Mean Squared Displacement (MSD) — calculateMSD
text: df data frame must include minimum - trace (track ID), x, y t (real coords) method string. Either "ensemble" "timeaveraged" (default) N numeric variable MSD. dt 1/N number data points (4 recommended) short numeric variable shortest number points analyse. Note, uses number frames start, number points track, .e. track <short points many gaps remain

title: Calculate Mean Squared Displacement (MSD) — calculateMSD
text: list data frame vector

title: Calculate Mean Squared Displacement (MSD) — calculateMSD
code: xmlPath <- system.file("extdata", "ExampleTrackMateData.xml", package="TrackMateR") tmObj <- readTrackMateXML(XMLpath = xmlPath) #> Units are:  1 pixel and 0.07002736 s  #> Spatial units are in pixels - consider transforming to real units #> Collecting spot data... #> Matching track data... #> Calculating distances... tmObj <- correctTrackMateData(tmObj, xyscalar = 0.04) #> Correcting XY scale.  tmDF <-  tmObj[[1]] msdObj <- calculateMSD(df = tmDF, method = "ensemble", N = 3, short = 8)

title: Calculate density of tracks — calculateTrackDensity
text: Calculate track, using starting frame, relative density tracks. use search radius find many tracks starting frame neighbours track. number neighbours normalised search circle, track corner image 2 neighbours density 8. Code calculating search area (intersection search circle image border) taken https://petrelharp.github.io/circle_rectangle_intersection/circle_rectangle_intersection.html

title: Calculate density of tracks — calculateTrackDensity
code: calculateTrackDensity(dataList, radius = 1)

title: Calculate density of tracks — calculateTrackDensity
text: dataList list data frame (must include minimum - trace (track ID), x, y frame (real coords)) calibration data frame radius numeric variable search radius (spatial units data)

title: Calculate density of tracks — calculateTrackDensity
text: data frame

title: Calculate density of tracks — calculateTrackDensity
code: xmlPath <- system.file("extdata", "ExampleTrackMateData.xml", package="TrackMateR") tmObj <- readTrackMateXML(XMLpath = xmlPath) #> Units are:  1 pixel and 0.07002736 s  #> Spatial units are in pixels - consider transforming to real units #> Collecting spot data... #> Matching track data... #> Calculating distances... tmObj <- correctTrackMateData(dataList = tmObj, xyscalar = 0.04) #> Correcting XY scale.  tdDF <- calculateTrackDensity(dataList = tmObj, radius = 2)

title: Compare datasets — compareDatasets
text: Requires TrackMate XML files organised subfolders named according condition. condition folders `Data/` within working directory, code run automatically. Otherwise, user asked locate top level folder contains condition subfolders. code process datasets individually, compile according condition compare across conditions. Outputs saved `Output/Plots/` working directory.

code: compareDatasets()

text: TrackMate data pixels /frames, data frame can converted function.

title: Correct distance and time of imported TrackMate data. — correctTrackMateData
code: correctTrackMateData(   dataList,   xyscalar = 1,   tscalar = 1,   xyunit = NULL,   tunit = NULL )

title: Correct distance and time of imported TrackMate data. — correctTrackMateData
text: dataList list data frame (track data) calibration data frame (TrackMate XML) xyscalar numeric multiplier correct pixel size original movie. Assumes isotropic scaling, .e. pixel height = pixel width tscalar numeric multiplier correct frame interval original movie. Frame interval tracked data. xyunit string describe spatial units tunit string describe temporal unit

title: Correct distance and time of imported TrackMate data. — correctTrackMateData
text: list two data frames

title: Correct distance and time of imported TrackMate data. — correctTrackMateData
code: xmlPath <- system.file("extdata", "ExampleTrackMateData.xml", package="TrackMateR") tmObj <- readTrackMateXML(XMLpath = xmlPath) #> Units are:  1 pixel and 0.07002736 s  #> Spatial units are in pixels - consider transforming to real units #> Collecting spot data... #> Matching track data... #> Calculating distances... # in the case where pixel size is 0.03 um and original data is 1 pixel, xyscalar = 0.03 tmObj <- correctTrackMateData(dataList = tmObj, xyscalar = 0.03) #> Correcting XY scale.

Fitting jump distance (JD) data — fittingJD
text: Jump Distances calculated given time lag. can described fitting curves data, either using histogram cumulative probability density function. Firtting histogram sensitive binning parameters ECDF performs better general use. idea behind analysis given : - Weimann et al. (2013) quantitative comparison single-dye tracking analysis tools using Monte Carlo simulations. PloS One 8, e64287. - Menssen & Mani (2019) Jump-Distance-Based Parameter Inference Scheme Particulate Trajectories, Biophysical Journal, 117: 1, 143-156. bulk code taken trackR JuG

title: Fitting jump distance (JD) data — fittingJD
code: fittingJD(   df,   mode = "ECDF",   nPop = 1,   init,   units = c("um", "s"),   timeRes = 1,   breaks = 100 )

title: Fitting jump distance (JD) data — fittingJD
text: df data frame column named jump jump distances mode string indicated ECDF (default) hist (histogram) nPop number populations diffusing species (1, 2 3) init initialisation parameters nls fit example list(D2 = 200,  D1 = 0.1) list(D2 = 0.01,  D1=0.1, D3=10, D4=100) units character vector describe units (defaults um, micrometres  s, seconds) timeRes time resolution per unit jump. Frame interval 0.5 s jump interval two steps, timeRes = 1. breaks number bins histogram. ECDF breaks can high e.g. 100, mode = "hist" low, perhaps 30.

title: Fitting jump distance (JD) data — fittingJD
text: ggplot

title: Fitting jump distance (JD) data — fittingJD
code: xmlPath <- system.file("extdata", "ExampleTrackMateData.xml", package="TrackMateR") tmObj <- readTrackMateXML(XMLpath = xmlPath) #> Units are:  1 pixel and 0.07002736 s  #> Spatial units are in pixels - consider transforming to real units #> Collecting spot data... #> Matching track data... #> Calculating distances... tmObj <- correctTrackMateData(tmObj, xyscalar = 0.04) #> Correcting XY scale.  jdObj <- calculateJD(dataList = tmObj, deltaT = 2) jdDF <- jdObj[[1]] fittingJD(df = jdDF, mode = "ECDF", nPop = 2, breaks = 100, timeRes = 0.06)

title: Make Summary Report — makeSummaryReport
text: Generate several plots visualise TrackMate data generate report. use um ggsave currently save unicode PDF reliably. code switchable accommodate making "report" (one dataset) "summary" (several related datasets combined)

title: Make Summary Report — makeSummaryReport
code: makeSummaryReport(   tmList,   msdList,   jumpList,   tddf,   titleStr = "",   subStr = "",   auto = FALSE,   summary = FALSE )

title: Make Summary Report — makeSummaryReport
text: tmList list trackmate data calibration msdList MSD summary alpha list = output calculateMSD() jumpList list data frame jump data variable passed timeRes tddf data frame track density data titleStr string used title report subStr string used subtitle report auto boolean selects returning patchwork report list patchwork report data frame summary summary boolean selects summary

title: Make Summary Report — makeSummaryReport
text: patchwork ggplot list patchwork ggplot data frame summary data

title: Make Summary Report — makeSummaryReport
code: xmlPath <- system.file("extdata", "ExampleTrackMateData.xml", package="TrackMateR") tmObj <- readTrackMateXML(XMLpath = xmlPath) #> Units are:  1 pixel and 0.07002736 s  #> Spatial units are in pixels - consider transforming to real units #> Collecting spot data... #> Matching track data... #> Calculating distances... tmObj <- correctTrackMateData(tmObj, xyscalar = 0.04) #> Correcting XY scale.  tmDF <- tmObj[[1]] calibrationDF <- tmObj[[2]] msdObj <- calculateMSD(df = tmDF, method = "ensemble", N = 3, short = 8) jdObj <- calculateJD(dataList = tmObj, deltaT = 1) tdDF <- calculateTrackDensity(dataList = tmObj, radius = 1.5) fileName <- tools::file_path_sans_ext(basename(xmlPath)) reportObj <- makeSummaryReport(tmList = tmObj, msdList = msdObj, jumpList = jdObj, tddf = tdDF, titleStr = "Report", subStr = fileName, auto = TRUE)

what: Make a plot of MSD data — plot_tm_MSD
title: Make a plot of MSD data — plot_tm_MSD
text: Generate plot MSD series increasing time lags. Input output CalculateMSD(), plot display ensemble time-averaged MSD (whatever requested) fit first four points displayed evaluate alpha. Diffusion coefficient fit displayed top-left.

title: Make a plot of MSD data — plot_tm_MSD
code: plot_tm_MSD(   df,   units = c("um", "s"),   bars = FALSE,   xlog = FALSE,   ylog = FALSE,   auto = FALSE )

title: Make a plot of MSD data — plot_tm_MSD
text: df MSD summary = output calculateMSD() units character vector describe units (defaults um, micrometres  s, seconds) bars boolean request error bars (1 x SD) xlog boolean request log10 x axis ylog boolean request log10 y axis auto boolean request plot , TRUE gives plot D list

title: Make a plot of MSD data — plot_tm_MSD
text: ggplot ggplot variable

title: Make a plot of MSD data — plot_tm_MSD
code: xmlPath <- system.file("extdata", "ExampleTrackMateData.xml", package="TrackMateR") datalist <- readTrackMateXML(XMLpath = xmlPath) #> Units are:  1 pixel and 0.07002736 s  #> Spatial units are in pixels - consider transforming to real units #> Collecting spot data... #> Matching track data... #> Calculating distances... data <-  datalist[[1]] # use the ensemble method and only look at tracks with more than 8 points msdobj <- calculateMSD(df = data, method = "ensemble", N = 3, short = 8) msddf <- msdobj[[1]] plot_tm_MSD(msddf, bars = FALSE)
